/meta skills "add this the knowledge about tools to the relevant skill(s): Based on verified sources, here's the complete list of Claude Code built-in tools:

## Claude Code Built-in Tools

### File Operations
**Read** - Read files from the local filesystem (supports text, images, PDFs, Jupyter notebooks)

**Write** - Write new files to the local filesystem

**Edit** - Perform exact string replacements in files

**MultiEdit** - Make multiple edits to a single file in one operation

**NotebookEdit** - Edit Jupyter notebook cells (.ipynb files)

### Search and Navigation
**Glob** - Fast file pattern matching with glob patterns (e.g., "**/*.js")

**Grep** - Powerful search tool built on ripgrep with regex support

**LS** - List files and directories

### Command Execution
**Bash** - Execute bash commands in a persistent shell session

**BashOutput** - Retrieve output from running background bash shells

**KillShell** - Terminate background bash shells

### Web Operations
**WebFetch** - Fetch and analyze content from URLs

**WebSearch** - Search the web for up-to-date information

### Task Management
**TodoWrite** - Create and manage structured task lists for coding sessions

**TodoRead** - Read existing task lists

**ExitPlanMode** - Exit planning mode when ready to implement code

### Agent/Delegation
**Task** - Launch specialized agents for complex, multi-step tasks

### Special Commands
**SlashCommand** - Execute slash commands within the conversation

---

## Quick Reference by Category

| Category | Tools |
|----------|-------|
| **File Read/Write** | Read, Write, Edit, MultiEdit, NotebookEdit |
| **Search** | Grep, Glob, LS |
| **Execution** | Bash, BashOutput, KillShell |
| **Web** | WebFetch, WebSearch |
| **Organization** | TodoWrite, TodoRead |
| **Planning** | ExitPlanMode |
| **Delegation** | Task |

---

## Additional Tools via MCP Servers

Beyond built-ins, Claude Code can access tools through connected MCP servers:

**mcp__ide__getDiagnostics** - Get language diagnostics from VS Code

**mcp__ide__executeCode** - Execute Python code in Jupyter kernel

Plus any additional MCP servers you configure like gemini-cli, firecrawl, playwright, etc.

---

## For Your Subagent Configuration

Your corrected `astro-architect` tools list:

```yaml
tools: Bash, Glob, Grep, LS, Read, Edit, MultiEdit, Write, WebFetch, TodoWrite, WebSearch
```

Or if you want to be comprehensive and inherit all tools + MCP:

```yaml
# Omit the tools field entirely to inherit all available tools from the main thread
```"

Review the @skills/use-workflows/ skill. currently it has exclusively predefined planning workflows, however i want to define workflows from different dimensions that produce completely different results / phases / deliverables / behaviors from claude agents. Here are some things i'd like to be able to do (some of which are implemented, some of which are not): 
- define different workflows with different phases.
- define what happens in each phase and the phases behavior (parallel agents, sequential agents, main agent only, main agents role such as reviewing deliverables, setting custome deliverables, etc.)
- since i want certain subagents to be reused across workflows, i want to define specific prompts for the different subagents depending on the workflows (such as what deliverables are expected and where to store them, reviewing previous phases work for context and where to find it, the scope of its job, etc) 
- I want to be able to customize when the main agent asks for my approval or asks me questions stopping the chat before proceeding with the next phases. 
- Open to other suggestions to make workflow presets that can handle phases, deliverables, human in the loop, subagent orchestrations, and other smart things that it should be able to handle.

Please review the current implementation, and suggest different approaches to enhance / improve the architecture for my goal. ultrathink

Review the @skills/use-workflows/ skill. currently it has exclusively predefined planning workflows, however i want to define workflows from different dimensions that produce completely different results / phases / deliverables / behaviors from claude agents. Here are some things i'd like to be able to do (some of which are implemented, some of which are not): 
- define different workflows with different phases.
- define what happens in each phase and the phases behavior (parallel agents, sequential agents, main agent only, main agents role such as reviewing deliverables, setting custome deliverables, etc.)
- since i want certain subagents to be reused across workflows, i want to define specific prompts for the different subagents depending on the workflows (such as what deliverables are expected and where to store them, reviewing previous phases work for context and where to find it, the scope of its job, etc) 
- I want to be able to customize when the main agent asks for my approval or asks me questions stopping the chat before proceeding with the next phases.
- i also want phases that can be either strict (must be followed precisely) or loose (allowing the agent to decide the approach based on suggestions) or inbetween (main agent must intelligently decide which subagents / skills to use based on the context)
- I also want to incorporate claude code skills into this as well. 
- Open to other suggestions to make workflow presets that can handle phases, deliverables, human in the loop, subagent orchestrations, and other smart things that it should be able to handle.

Please review the current implementation, and suggest different approaches to enhance / improve the architecture for my goal. ultrathink

improve the plan considering these notes:  - Insert task to describe the MVP execution path (load YAML workflow → iterate
    phases → emit metadata) before advanced features.
  - Add task defining engine data models: workflow schema, phase schema, context
    structure, deliverable record, checkpoint record.
  - Add task detailing strict/loose/adaptive execution logic and how each maps to
    phase behaviors (parallel, sequential, main-only).
  - Add task documenting checkpoint flow: approval options, retry handling, abort
    handling, context updates.
  - Add task documenting gap-check flow: evaluation criteria ingestion, retry/
    escalation logic, metadata capture.
  - Add task specifying inline scripting API: available helpers, context IO,
    error handling.
  - Add task listing required Node-based tooling (mustache, yq fallback, jq) and
    how the engine invokes them.
  - Add task defining testing matrix for new engine workflows (unit coverage for
    loaders/executor, integration run for each workflow type).
  - Add task outlining workflow authoring support: schema validation, helper
    scripts/templates for new workflows, documentation updates.

• - ⚠️ The plan still scopes JSON→YAML conversion work even though we
    explicitly said that isn’t needed. It adds tools/converter.sh,
    a migration guide, loader/unit tests that auto-convert legacy
    JSON, and backward-compat scenarios that depend on that converter

    use-workflows/IMPLEMENTATION_PLAN_V2.md:3401-3405, skills/use-
    workflows/IMPLEMENTATION_PLAN_V2.md:3671-3674, skills/use-workflows/

- High – tools/new-workflow.sh:47-156: The scaffolder writes literal
    WORKFLOW_NAME/{{...}} placeholders because the here-docs are quoted
    (<<'EOF'), so none of the bash variables expand. Every generated workflow
    YAML will contain the string WORKFLOW_NAME instead of the caller’s name,
    making the tool unusable. Drop the quotes on the here-doc delimiters (or
    post-process with sed) so ${WORKFLOW_NAME} and ${OUTPUT_DIR} are interpolated
    before writing the file.
  - High – DATA_MODELS.md:6-69, schemas/workflow.schema.json:3-112, tools/
    validator.sh:50-137, ARCHITECTURE.md:5-41: The model/schema currently forces
    a single execution_mode at the workflow level and validates every phase
    against that one mode. Requirements call for mixing strict/loose/adaptive
    in the same workflow, and real workflows (e.g., finalization phases) need
    main-only behavior even when discovery is adaptive. With the present schema/
    validator, any adaptive workflow would reject a main-only phase, and mixed-
    mode workflows are impossible. Please introduce a per-phase mode (or similar)
    and update the docs/schema/validator so each phase can declare its execution
    mode while still supporting a workflow-level default if you want one.

here's some notes: • - engine/script-interpreter.sh:24 – mktemp --suffix=.js breaks on macOS (the
    target environment); BSD mktemp doesn’t support --suffix, so every script
    execution fails before Node even runs. Use a portable pattern (e.g., mktemp
    "${TMPDIR:-/tmp}/workflow-script.XXXXXX.js" and append the suffix manually).
  - engine/script-interpreter.sh:28 – timeout "${timeout}ms" won’t run: GNU
    timeout only understands seconds (with optional s, m, etc.) and macOS ships
    a different utility without millisecond support. Converting the millisecond
    value to seconds (or using perl/node timeouts) is required to avoid immediate
    execution failures.
  - engine/template-renderer.sh:99-110 – the jq expression that builds
    render_context is syntactically invalid (output_dir: $context.feature.name |
    ".temp/" + .). As soon as we try to render a prompt template, jq exits with a
    syntax error and subagent spawning stops. Wrap the pipe in parentheses (e.g.,
    output_dir: ($context.feature.name | ".temp/" + .)) and, while you’re there,
    pass the real phase JSON instead of the current "{}" placeholder so templates
    get useful data.
  - engine/subagent-pool.sh:67-76 – parallel subagents run in background jobs
    but each one mutates context.json via subagent_spawned/add_deliverable. Those
    writes aren’t synchronized, so concurrent processes race and clobber each
    other’s updates. Either serialize the updates (e.g., run batches sequentially
    for now or add file locks) before we rely on parallel execution. determine what's actually valid and then proceed with the fixes

/meta skills create a new skill based on these instructions:
---
name: doc-research
description: Research official documentation, API references, and best practices for the tech stack (Astro, Vue 3, Appwrite, TypeScript, Tailwind, etc.). Use when user needs to verify correct usage, find implementation patterns, debug library-specific issues, or understand framework conventions. Provides comprehensive research findings from cached outputs, MCP servers, and authoritative sources.
---

# Documentation Research Skill

Research official documentation and best practices for the user's tech stack. This skill orchestrates specialized subagents to find authoritative information efficiently.

## Tech Stack Coverage

This skill provides research for:
- **Frontend**: Astro, Vue 3 (Composition API), TypeScript
- **State**: Nanostores, VueUse
- **Backend**: Appwrite (client SDK, functions, auth)
- **Styling**: Tailwind CSS v4
- **Validation**: Zod
- **UI Libraries**: headlessui/vue, floating-ui/vue, shadcn-ui/vue
- **Additional**: See SITEMAP.md for complete list

## Research Workflow

### Phase 1: Cache Review (Always First)
1. Deploy `cache-researcher` subagent
2. Search `outputs/` folder for recent relevant findings
3. Ignore files older than 60 days
4. Return cache status: FOUND (sufficient) or INSUFFICIENT (need research)

### Phase 2: Active Research (Only if Cache Insufficient)
1. Deploy **in parallel**:
   - `mcp-researcher` subagent - Uses Context7, Astro Doc MCP for official docs
   - `best-practice-researcher` subagent - Uses Tavily for community patterns/articles
2. Both subagents write findings to `outputs/` folder:
   - Format: `doc_[topic]_[YYYY-MM-DD].md` (for MCP research)
   - Format: `web_[topic]_[YYYY-MM-DD].md` (for web research)
3. Wait for both to complete

### Phase 3: Synthesis & Handoff
1. Read all relevant files from `outputs/`
2. Synthesize findings into a concise summary for main agent
3. Highlight:
   - Official documentation findings
   - Best practices discovered
   - Recommended implementation approach
   - Key gotchas or version-specific notes
4. Present summary to user

## Instructions for Claude

When this skill is invoked:

1. **Start with cache-researcher**: Always deploy this subagent first. Do not skip cache check.

2. **Evaluate cache results**: If cache-researcher finds recent, relevant documentation, use those findings. Only proceed to Phase 2 if cache is insufficient.

3. **Parallel deployment**: If research needed, deploy both mcp-researcher and best-practice-researcher simultaneously. Do not wait for one to finish before starting the other.

4. **Let subagents work independently**: Each subagent has its own instructions and will handle writing to outputs/. Do not micromanage their process.

5. **Synthesize findings**: After subagents complete, read the output files they created and present a cohesive summary to the user. Include:
   - What was found in cache (if anything)
   - What new research uncovered
   - Practical next steps
   - Links to authoritative sources

6. **Be concise**: The summary should be comprehensive but information-dense. No fluff, no repetition, just actionable insights.

## Examples

**Example 1: Cache Hit**
```
User: "What's the proper way to handle Appwrite authentication in Astro SSR?"

1. Deploy cache-researcher
2. Found: doc_appwrite-auth-ssr_2025-10-15.md (recent, relevant)
3. Summarize findings from cache
4. No additional research needed
```

**Example 2: Cache Miss - Full Research**
```
User: "How do I implement Suspense in Vue 3 with async components in Astro?"

1. Deploy cache-researcher
2. Result: No recent files found
3. Deploy mcp-researcher + best-practice-researcher in parallel
4. mcp-researcher creates: doc_vue-suspense-astro_2025-10-31.md
5. best-practice-researcher creates: web_vue-suspense-patterns_2025-10-31.md
6. Read both files, synthesize comprehensive summary for user
```

**Example 3: Partial Cache - Supplement Research**
```
User: "What's new in Tailwind v4 for Vue components?"

1. Deploy cache-researcher  
2. Found: doc_tailwind-v4_2025-09-20.md (relevant but older)
3. Deploy mcp-researcher for updated info
4. Creates: doc_tailwind-v4-vue_2025-10-31.md
5. Synthesize findings from both cache and new research
```

## Notes

- SITEMAP.md contains curated list of authoritative documentation sources
- Subagents will reference SITEMAP for known-good documentation URLs
- This skill does NOT analyze the codebase - assumes user provides necessary context
- This skill does NOT implement solutions - only provides research findings
- Main agent uses findings to determine implementation approach

# Documentation Sitemap

Curated list of authoritative documentation sources for the tech stack.

## Framework Documentation

- **Astro**: https://docs.astro.build - Official SSR framework docs, routing, integrations, middleware, Cloudflare adapter
- **Astro Examples**: https://github.com/withastro/astro/tree/main/examples - Official example implementations
- **Vue 3 Guide**: https://vuejs.org/guide/ - Composition API, reactivity, lifecycle, components
- **Vue 3 API Reference**: https://vuejs.org/api/ - Complete API documentation
- **TypeScript Handbook**: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/ - Official TS documentation

## Astro Integrations

- **@astrojs/vue**: https://docs.astro.build/en/guides/integrations-guide/vue/ - Vue integration for Astro
- **@astrojs/cloudflare**: https://docs.astro.build/en/guides/integrations-guide/cloudflare/ - Cloudflare Pages adapter
- **@astrojs/sitemap**: https://docs.astro.build/en/guides/integrations-guide/sitemap/ - Sitemap generation
- **astrojs-service-worker**: https://github.com/tatethurston/astrojs-service-worker - PWA support for Astro

## State Management

- **Nanostores**: https://github.com/nanostores/nanostores - Core documentation and patterns
- **@nanostores/vue**: https://github.com/nanostores/vue - Vue 3 integration
- **@nanostores/persistent**: https://github.com/nanostores/persistent - Persistent storage
- **VueUse**: https://vueuse.org - Collection of Vue Composition utilities

## Styling

- **Tailwind CSS v4**: https://tailwindcss.com/docs - Official v4 documentation
- **@tailwindcss/vite**: https://tailwindcss.com/docs/installation/vite - Vite integration
- **Tailwind with Astro**: https://docs.astro.build/en/guides/styling/#tailwind - Astro-specific Tailwind setup

## UI Components & Libraries

- **headlessui/vue**: https://headlessui.com - Unstyled, accessible UI components for Vue
- **floating-ui/vue**: https://floating-ui.com/docs/vue - Positioning library for tooltips, popovers, dropdowns
- **shadcn-ui/vue**: https://www.shadcn-vue.com - Re-usable components built with Radix Vue and Tailwind
- **Iconify Vue**: https://iconify.design/docs/icon-components/vue/ - Icon system for Vue
- **sweetalert2**: https://sweetalert2.github.io - Beautiful modals/alerts
- **emoji-picker-element**: https://github.com/nolanlawson/emoji-picker-element - Lightweight emoji picker

## Backend/BaaS

- **Appwrite Docs**: https://appwrite.io/docs - Complete backend platform documentation
- **Appwrite Web SDK**: https://appwrite.io/docs/sdks#client - Frontend SDK reference
- **Appwrite Functions**: https://appwrite.io/docs/products/functions - Serverless functions (Node.js, Bun, Python)
- **Appwrite Auth**: https://appwrite.io/docs/products/auth - Authentication patterns
- **Appwrite Database**: https://appwrite.io/docs/products/databases - Database queries and relationships
- **Appwrite Storage**: https://appwrite.io/docs/products/storage - File upload and management
- **node-appwrite**: https://github.com/appwrite/sdk-for-node - Node.js server SDK for functions
- **appwrite-utils**: https://github.com/Meldiron/appwrite-utils - Community utilities for Appwrite

## Validation & Data

- **Zod**: https://zod.dev - TypeScript-first schema validation
- **libphonenumber-js**: https://github.com/catamphetamine/libphonenumber-js - Phone number validation
- **metascraper**: https://metascraper.js.org - Metadata extraction from URLs

## Media Processing

- **@ffmpeg/ffmpeg**: https://github.com/ffmpeg/ffmpeg.wasm - WASM video processing
- **video.js**: https://videojs.com/guides/ - HTML5 video player
- **browser-image-compression**: https://github.com/Donaldcwl/browser-image-compression - Client-side image compression
- **Sharp**: https://sharp.pixelplumbing.com - High-performance image processing (Node.js functions)

## Charts & Visualization

- **ECharts**: https://echarts.apache.org/en/index.html - Powerful charting library
- **vue-echarts**: https://github.com/ecomfe/vue-echarts - Vue 3 wrapper for ECharts
- **D3.js**: https://d3js.org - Data visualization primitives

## Utilities

- **es-toolkit**: https://es-toolkit.slash.page - Modern Lodash alternative
- **Luxon**: https://moment.github.io/luxon/ - DateTime library
- **ulid-workers**: https://github.com/perry-mitchell/ulid-workers - ULID generation
- **idb**: https://github.com/jakearchibald/idb - IndexedDB wrapper

## Testing

- **Vitest**: https://vitest.dev - Fast Vite-native test framework
- **@testing-library/vue**: https://testing-library.com/docs/vue-testing-library/intro/ - Vue testing utilities
- **@vue/test-utils**: https://test-utils.vuejs.org - Official Vue testing utilities
- **happy-dom**: https://github.com/capricorn86/happy-dom - Fast DOM implementation for testing

## Build Tools

- **Vite**: https://vitejs.dev/guide/ - Build tool and dev server
- **Wrangler**: https://developers.cloudflare.com/workers/wrangler/ - Cloudflare tooling
- **pnpm**: https://pnpm.io/motivation - Fast, disk space efficient package manager

## Payment Integration

- **Stripe JS**: https://stripe.com/docs/js - Frontend Stripe integration
- **Stripe Node**: https://github.com/stripe/stripe-node - Server-side Stripe SDK

## Monitoring & Analytics

- **Sentry Astro**: https://docs.sentry.io/platforms/javascript/guides/astro/ - Error tracking for Astro
- **Microsoft Clarity**: https://clarity.microsoft.com/docs - Session replay and analytics

## Community Resources

- **Astro Discord**: https://astro.build/chat - Real-time community help
- **Vue Discord**: https://discord.com/invite/vue - Vue community discussions
- **Appwrite Discord**: https://appwrite.io/discord - Appwrite developer community
- **Stack Overflow - Astro**: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/astro - Q&A for Astro
- **Stack Overflow - Vue3**: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vue.js+vue-composition-api - Vue 3 specific questions

• - Bug – subagent outputs land in {{output_dir}} folders
    engine/subagent-pool.sh:138-168 pulls config.output_path verbatim and never
    expands placeholders like {{output_dir}}. Default templates rely on that
    token, so the engine will create directories literally named {{output_dir}}
    and drop deliverables there, breaking subsequent phases and metadata
    tracking. Please run the path through substitute_template_vars (or similar)
    before using it.
  - Bug – script helper still with empty phase context
    In engine/script-interpreter.sh:50-59, the wrapped Node script defines const
    phase = context.phases.current ? {} : {};, so phase is always {}. Every
    sample script (adaptive selection, gap checks, checkpoints) expects phase.id/
    phase.behavior; with the empty object those comparisons fail, and scripts
    silently misbehave (e.g., gap checks never match deliverables to the current
    phase). Pass the real phase JSON into the interpreter and inject it into
    the wrapper.
  - Bug – timeout command assumption
    engine/script-interpreter.sh:34-41 shells out to timeout, which isn’t
    available on macOS by default and only accepts second granularity. On a
    standard Claude Code environment this will error before the script runs.
    Either rely on Node’s setTimeout/AbortController for execution limits or gate
    the call behind a dependency check/fallback.
  - Quality gap – prompt rendering lacks real phase data
    Because run_subagent_batch fabricates a stub {id, name, description} (engine/
    subagent-pool.sh:149-154), prompt templates never receive the actual phase
    title/description from the workflow, undermining the whole “workflow-specific
    prompts” goal. Once you pass the real phase object the templates (and docs
    from Phase 0) line up.
